dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, welcome back to the show, everyone. We’ve got some pretty significant news coming out of the Senate today, specifically concerning, uh, tax reform.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, welcome back to the show, everyone. We've got some pretty significant news coming out of the Senate today, specifically concerning, uh, tax reform.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, big one, Host_A. Bekbolat Orynbekov, from the Committee on Finance and Budget, he, uh, he tabled an initiative to really shake up our special tax regimes.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, big one, Host_A. Bekbolat Orynbekov, from the Committee on Finance and Budget, he, uh, he tabled an initiative to really shake up our special tax regimes.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: During today™s Senate discussion on the draft of the new Tax Code, member of the Committee on Finance and Budget Bekbolat Orynbekov presented an initiative to reform the system of special tax regimes (STR).

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, really? Special Tax Regimes? I thought we had, like, a bunch of those already. What’s the big change he’s proposing?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, really? Special Tax Regimes? I thought we had, like, a bunch of those already. What's the big change he's proposing?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, get this: currently, we have seven different regimes. His proposal? [overlaps] To cut them down to just three.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, get this: currently, we have seven different regimes. His proposal? To cut them down to just three.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: According to the proposal, the current seven regimes would be reduced to just three:

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Seven to three? Wow, that’s, uh, that’s a pretty drastic reduction. What do these three look like?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Seven to three? Wow, that's, uh, that's a pretty drastic reduction. What do these three look like?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it is! So, the first one is for self-employed individuals. It’s super straightforward: a 4% tax rate on annual income up to 15 million tenge. And here’s the kicker – no individual entrepreneur registration needed.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it is! So, the first one is for self-employed individuals. It's super straightforward: a four percent tax rate on annual income up to fifteen million tenge. And here's the kicker - no individual entrepreneur registration needed.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The first regime will be intended for self-employed individuals. It would involve a 4% tax rate on annual income up to 15 million tenge. Registration as an individual entrepreneur would not be required.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Ooh, no IE registration, that’s actually a huge deal for, like, freelancers or people with side hustles, right? That simplifies things a lot.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Ooh, no I E registration, that's actually a huge deal for, like, freelancers or people with side hustles, right? That simplifies things a lot.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. Then, the second regime is for, uh, more established entrepreneurs, based on a simplified declaration. This one targets annual incomes up to 600,000 Monthly Calculation Indexes.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. Then, the second regime is for, uh, more established entrepreneurs, based on a simplified declaration. This one targets annual incomes up to six hundred thousand Monthly Calculation Indexes.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The second regime will be based on a simplified declaration. It targets entrepreneurs with an annual income of up to 600,000 Monthly Calculation Indexes (MCI)

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Six hundred thousand MCIs? That sounds like a lot. And what about the tax rate there? Is it still 4%?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Six hundred thousand M C Is? That sounds like a lot. And what about the tax rate there? Is it still four percent?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It is, a base 4%. But get this: local maslikhats, or regional councils, they’ll have the flexibility to adjust it, uh, anywhere between 2% and 6%. And there are no limits on employees under this one.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It is, a base four percent. But get this: local maslikhats, or regional councils, they'll have the flexibility to adjust it, uh, anywhere between two percent and six percent. And there are no limits on employees under this one.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The base tax rate of 4% will be maintained, but local maslikhats (regional councils) will be able to adjust it within a range of 2% to 6%. This regime will not impose limits on the number of employees.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: No limits on employees and local councils can adjust the rate? That’s actually really interesting, provides some local control and, like, flexibility.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No limits on employees and local councils can adjust the rate? That's actually really interesting, provides some local control and, like, flexibility.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And finally, the third regime is specifically for peasant and farming households. It, um, largely keeps existing norms, but the unified land tax will be swapped for an individual income tax.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And finally, the third regime is specifically for peasant and farming households. It, um, largely keeps existing norms, but the unified land tax will be swapped for an individual income tax.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The third regime will apply to peasant and farming households. It will largely retain the norms of current legislation. However, under the updated approach, the unified land tax will be replaced with individual income tax.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, what’s the overall goal here, Bekbolat Orynbekov, uh, what’s he trying to achieve with all these changes?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, what's the overall goal here, Bekbolat Orynbekov, uh, what's he trying to achieve with all these changes?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: He’s pretty clear: simplify the tax system, reduce the administrative burden on businesses, and really encourage self-employment across the country. It’s part of a broader tax reform.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: He's pretty clear: simplify the tax system, reduce the administrative burden on businesses, and really encourage self-employment across the country. It's part of a broader tax reform.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Bekbolat Orynbekov stated that this initiative aims to simplify the tax system, reduce administrative burden on businesses, and encourage self-employment across the country. The proposed changes are part of a broader tax reform under discussion within the new Tax Code.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Sounds like it's all aiming for a much more, like, user-friendly and streamlined approach for businesses and individuals. This is definitely one to watch as part of the new Tax Code discussions.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Sounds like it's all aiming for a much more, like, user-friendly and streamlined approach for businesses and individuals. This is definitely one to watch as part of the new Tax Code discussions.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. It could really change the landscape for many small businesses and individuals, you know?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. It could really change the landscape for many small businesses and individuals, you know?
